title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

items.title: France demands Volkswagen faces new trial over Dieselgate emissions—one of the biggest scandals to hit the auto industry
items.description: Volkswagen admitted in 2015 it had sold 11 million vehicles equipped with devices designed to cheat environmental regulations.

items.title: Democrats May Be Down, but Their Appetite for Voting Hasn’t Dimmed
items.description: They have had strong turnout in special elections and in the early voting for today’s elections.

items.title: Donald Trump’s strategy to weaken the dollar could already be a success—in making it too expensive for Americans to travel to Europe
items.description: Virgin Atlantic, which made $1.3 billion from the U.S. last year, is seeing a decline in demand from Americans.

items.title: As Trump Stokes Uncertainty, the Fed Asks Businesses Where It Hurts
items.description: The central bank’s outreach to companies has taken on new significance as the outlook for growth and inflation gets cloudier.

items.title: The Most Expensive Judicial Race in U.S. History, and a Growing Demand for Ivermectin
items.description: Plus, the return of the rotating restaurant.

items.title: Demis Hassabis on Isomorphic’s $600 million raise, AI, and healthcare’s future
items.description: Demis Hassabis, cofounder of DeepMind and 2024 Nobel Laureate, talks to Fortune about his AI drug discovery startup, Isomorphic Labs.

items.description: China’s former top spy catcher is among six security enforcers targeted as the Trump administration turns its attention to human rights issues in the ...

items.title: What I Learned About Trump’s Second Term by Reading His First 100 Executive Orders
items.description: Even with Republican congressional majorities, Trump favors the flourish of the order over the hassle of lawmaking.

items.title: President Trump wants action from the Fed, but one bank president says April 2 has only delayed their cuts

items.title: Hooters was dumped by its NASCAR team and sued for only hiring ‘Hooters Girls’ to serve customers. Now it’s filed for bankruptcy
items.description: Hooters, based in Atlanta, was founded in Clearwater, Florida, in 1983. Trouble had been brewing for a while.

items.title: The Irving Family Provides Many Jobs to a Canadian Province, But Also Draws Concerns
items.description: The Irving family businesses dominate Saint John, New Brunswick. They are a major employer, but residents say those jobs have come with a steep cost.

items.title: Israel’s Military Strikes Near Beirut, Killing Three
items.description: The attack was the second in less than a week, raising fears that a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah could unravel.
